title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and establishes the Great Lakes Research Council. The Great Lakes Research Council is established to advise and coordinate Federal research activities for ecosystem protection of the Great Lakes. Within one year of enactment, the Council will assess research needs, Federal expertise, and make recommendations for fulfilling the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals. The Great Lakes Research Council is tasked with providing recommendations for Federal research priorities, participating in research-related events, advising on data collection, establishing a data base, and ensuring timely dissemination of research findings. The Council is composed of research managers from various agencies with expertise in the Great Lakes ecosystem. Non-Federal individuals can also serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected by members for a two-year term, with a limit of two consecutive terms. Members are entitled to compensation for travel expenses. Interagency cooperation is emphasized. Interagency cooperation is essential for implementing recommendations and providing necessary resources or information to achieve the purposes of the Act. The Council will invite the International Joint Commission to serve as the principal coordinating body and Secretariat for international cooperation. Agencies on the Council may reimburse costs for activities conducted by the International Joint Commission. This Act will not affect the authority of any Federal department to conduct Great Lakes research activities. The Act defines key terms such as "Council" as the Great Lakes Research Council, "Great Lakes" including specific bodies of water, "Great Lakes research" as scientific application in the ecosystem, and "Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement" as a bilateral agreement between the US and Canada.
